text:
I can't seem to install anything on Julia anymore. It keeps finding conflicts with packages that aren't even a dependency of the thing I'm trying to install.
Installing the same packages in another machine with the same Julia version works

It seems the julia registry in one of my machines is broken. Has anyone been through this before?

text: that's why you should use different environments  for different tasks :slightly_smiling_face:  unless you do need _all_ of them together :grimacing:

elements.text: that's why you should use different environments  for different tasks

text: I have been using different environments (Projects?) for different tasks, but I do have some packages in the general registry

elements.text: I have been using different environments (Projects?) for different tasks, but I do have some packages in the general registry

text: Do you know how I can fix this?

elements.text: Do you know how I can fix this?

text: I tend to keep only few general dev tools in the global environment, and then use local environments for specific tasks

elements.text: I tend to keep only few general dev tools in the global environment, and then use local environments for specific tasks

text: It has happened to me before. I ended up nuking everything and started from scratch.

elements.text: It has happened to me before. I ended up nuking everything and started from scratch.

text: What do you mean nuking everything? Removing `~/.julia`?

elements.text: What do you mean nuking everything? Removing

text: I _**don't**_ recommend deleting entire `~/.julia` directory, it's rarely the solution
Yes. removing `~/.julia`. I had no choice. Nobody was able to suggest a fix.

elements.text: . I had no choice. Nobody was able to suggest a fix.

text: Does starting Julia again after repopulate `.julia`?

elements.text: Does starting Julia again after repopulate

text: I started adding back the packages in stages. And was able to narrow down to one package that screwed up everything.

elements.text: I started adding back the packages in stages. And was able to narrow down to one package that screwed up everything.

text: I decided not to use that package.

elements.text: I decided not to use that package.

text: yes, but you're going to redownload a lot of stuff.  and if you're a developer and have `dev`-ed packages, deleting entire `~/.julia` is simply a no-go

elements.text: yes, but you're going to redownload a lot of stuff.  and if you're a developer and have

text: in this case you're problem seems to be with the registry. delete it and you should be good to go

For the average user, it is not clear if understanding the problem and then fixing it costs less time than just reinstall everything
